Introduction

The Rajadhirat Ayeidawpon is an important document for Burmese history. It covers the period roughly from 1380 to 1425, the reign of the Mon King Razadarit, a period of endemic warfare which has been dubbed the 40 Years War.

References

Binnya Dala (no date) “Razadhirat Ayeidawpom” in Ayeidawpon Saung-twe thou-ma hout Myanma-min-mya Ayeidawpon. Yangon: Pansodan, pp. 149-329.

[Translation from the Burmese of Rajadhirat Ayeidawpon, See Binnyadala (n.d.)] `San Lwin Translation from Burmese: <https://drive.google.com/file/d/14EBUELGV1goytxxImN394p_Uo2rXZkn5/view?usp=sharing >`_

Thaw Kaung, U. (2004) “Ayedawbon Kyan, an Important Myanmar Literary Genre Recording Historical Events.” Journal of the Siam Society 88.1 & 2 (2000), pp. 21-33, republished in Selected Writings of U Thaw Kaung, Yangon: Myanmar Historical Commission, 2004, pp. 1-28.

`Locally-published translation from Mon: <https://drive.google.com/file/d/1H9l-s_U8svcCs4AqQct0S6ZU68ilUsEP/view?usp=sharing >`_

Note: Wikipedia Coverage

Existing Wikipedia article Razadarit Ayedawbon focuses only on the Burmese version of this work. There are also Thai language, Mon language and Pali language versions as well. The work can thus be characterized as Transnational history, but since Wikipedia’s historical coverage is organized along the lines of the nation state, the nature of this work is not adequately covered. This is an important issue because the longstanding belief is that the original version of this work was in Mon, not Burmese, and the version of this work in Thai is considered an important literary work composed during the restoration of Rama I in Thailand. (Source: My Wikipedia To-Do-List)
